Award.AwardTitle: PFI-TT: Flexible Electronic Devices for Harvesting Body Heat toward Self-Powered Wearable Health Monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project lies in enabling wearable devices that can be used for remote, vigilant, and long-term health monitoring. The COVID-19 pandemic has recently highlighted the acute need for such devices to manage/protect individual and public health, particularly for those with chronic underlying conditions. Continuous monitoring of multiple biomarkers is one of the key enablers of precision and personalized medicine. However, current products on the market are not capable of providing the medical and scientific community the necessary access to high-resolution and longitudinal data. These systems typically lack multiple sensing modalities while also suffering from short battery life. To address the need, wearable platforms must operate with no interruptions to collect high granularity data over time and establish individual health baselines. This can be accomplished by harvesting the excess energy from the human body and/or the environment to power the sensors and the electronics. Such battery-free devices have the potential to revolutionize the medical industry by empowering individuals to gain control of their own health while significantly reducing medical costs by decreasing the need for frequent doctor visits.<br/><br/>The project introduces a flexible electronic energy harvesting device that can be worn on the body to harvest excess body heat and convert it to electrical energy. The device relies on a unique liquid-metal material which conducts electricity like a metal while offering water-like viscosity to realize electrical circuitry with ultimate flexibility and stretchability. The technology is compatible with roll-to-roll manufacturing, a highly desirable attribute in flexible electronics to reduce costs. The primary goal of the project is to increase the technology readiness of the harvester to increase its commercialization potential. The research includes systematic studies geared toward assessing and improving the long-term reliability of the harvester while enhancing its manufacturability by introducing materials and processes that offer lower-cost and manufacturing ease without compromising device performance. Research tasks include new flexible materials for enhanced performance, comfort, and robustness. The new materials and devices will be tested on the human body during different physical activity levels and under different ambient conditions. The harvesters will be subjected to repetitive cycles of external stresses such as heat, moisture and mechanical deformation. The results will be used to identify potential failure mechanisms, materials and process solutions will address such mechanisms.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wearable electronic sensing technologies promise a pathway to enabling improved and personalizedhealth/wellness prediction and management.  Continuous monitoring of multiple biomarkers is viewed as one of the key enablers of precision and personalized medicine.  Unfortunately, as the sensing modalities incorporated in wearable devices continue to expand, electrical energy necessary to run them creeps up making it impossible to rely on existing wearables for continuous monitoring of health parameters. A promising solution to the above problem is to use various energy harvesting technologies to support and possibly eliminate the use of rechargeable batteries.  

The focus of this NSF project was to evaluate and improve the long-term reliability of a new technology designed to harvest body heat to power wearable electronics.  The technology, which relies on thermoelectricity provides a flexible platform, which can be incorporated into a wearable device worn on the human body.  The physical principle of the device is based on maintaining a temperature differential across many semiconductor elements.  When such a thermoelectric device is placed on the human body, the body heat flowing through each element produces a small voltage proportional to the temperature differential across them. These small voltages can be added to produce a larger voltage, which can be large enough to power an electronic device.  These devices are commonly referred to as thermoelectric generators (TEGs).

Commercial TEGs are rigid devices, which can not be easily incorporated in wearable devices. To address this challenge, PIs Ozturk and Dickey developed and patented a flexible TEG.  The work toward this new device was supported by an NSF funded Engineering Research Center, ASSIST. A key novelty of the flexible TEG is the use liquid metal EGaIn interconnects (a eutectic compound of Ga and In) to achieve not only flexible but a stretchable device. The device uses the same semiconductor elements used in ordinary devices eliminating the need to develop new thermoelectric materials, which is a siginificant advantage towards its commercialization.

The PFI project focused on different materials used in fabrication of these flexible TEGs, with the objective of improving their flexibility and performance while ensuring that the devices could withstand different environmental stresses.

Specifically, the project focused on a stretchable, low thermal conductivity silicone material and liquid metal interconnects.  Pores filled with air were incorporated in the silicone material using a process developed during the project.  It was shown that the thermal conductivity of silicone could be reduced by a factor of 2.5 by incorporating the pores. The materials and devices were subjected to both mechanical and thermal stresses.  It was demonstrated that flexible TEGs with porous silicone could withstand strain levels up to 300%.  It was also determined that deposition of the liquid metal interconnect on porous silicone material did not pose any reliability challenges.  Interconnects were tested as they were subjected to extreme levels of mechanical strain with no signs of failure up to unrealistically high strain levels.  Another reliability concern for the devices was behavior of liquid metal interconnects at subzero temperatures.  The concern stemmed from EGaIn'srelatively high melting point of 15C.  Devices fabricated using EGaIn and Galinstan interconnects were tested before and after freezing at sub-zero temperatures.  Galinstan was included in the work due to its higher melting poin of +19C. It was shown that neither EGaIn nor Galinstan TEGs were compromised when they were subjected to freezing temperatures.  In summary, flexible TEGs exhibited promising performance in terms of both energy harvesting levels and reliability.

A shortcoming of the flexible TEG technology is that it is more expensive than simply placing a battery compartment and charging electronics to a wearable device.  However, as the cost of materials go down, the feasability of incorporating a harvester in wearables will increase.  While it may be too soon to introduce the technology to the market, we believe it offers a promising solution for future wearables designed for continuous monitoring of health parameters.

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2024
Modified by: Mehmet C Ozturk
